case_title: PWD EMPLOYEES' UNION, BALOCHISTAN through Vice-President and others vs SECRETARY, COMMUNICATION AND WORKS DEPARTMENT, GOVERNMENT OF BALOCHISTAN QUETTA and others
reference_no_or_id: Constitutional Petition No,370 of 2010, Contempt Application No,34 of 2010 in C.P. No,370 of 2010, C.Ps. Nos.357, 379, 402 of 2011, 117, 844, 912 of 2012, 448, 502, 662, 962 of 2013 and 89 of 2014
appellant: PWD EMPLOYEES' UNION, BALOCHISTAN through Vice-President and others
respondant: SECRETARY, COMMUNICATION AND WORKS DEPARTMENT, GOVERNMENT OF BALOCHISTAN QUETTA and others
complaint_summary: The petitioners challenged the constitutionality of Rule 12 and 12-A of the Balochistan Civil Servants (Appointment, Promotion and Transfer) Rules, 2009, which provided preferential employment rights to widows and children of deceased or retired government servants.
investigation_summary: The court reviewed legislative history, including the Balochistan Civil Servants Act, 1974 and its subsequent amendments, and examined whether Rule 12 violated constitutional provisions such as Articles 25 and 27.
judgment_summary: The court held that Rule 12 and 12-A of the Balochistan Civil Servants (Appointment, Promotion and Transfer) Rules, 2009 were discriminatory and violated Articles 2A, 3, 4, 9, 18, 25, and 27 of the Constitution. The petitions were dismissed.
legal_arguments: Petitioners argued Rule 12 was beneficial legislation and did not violate constitutional provisions.
Respondents argued Rule 12 violated Articles 25 and 27 of the Constitution by creating a privileged class and undermining merit-based appointments.
sections: Section 25 of the Balochistan Civil Servants Act, 1974
key_issues: Whether Rule 12 violates the principle of equal protection under Articles 25 and 27 of the Constitution.
Whether Rule 12 conflicts with the parent statute, the Balochistan Civil Servants Act, 1974.

maxims.Equality before law: All persons similarly situated must be treated alike.

legal_terms.Judicial Review: The power of courts to assess the constitutionality of legislative and executive actions.

words_and_phrases.Intelligible differentia: A logical and clear distinction that justifies classification.

summary_vector_notes: The judgment examined the constitutionality of Rule 12 and 12-A of the Balochistan Civil Servants Rules, 2009, concluding that they violated fundamental rights under the Constitution by creating discriminatory classifications. The petitions were dismissed, and the rules were declared unconstitutional.
